, founded in 2000, is a public company that operates various travel website
travel-related content, such as editorial reviews of hotels, in addition to providing a free forum for user discussion. The company has about 2400 e
than 100 million monthly views. While revenue is primarily generated through advertising, user-generated content (such as photographs, ratings, and reviews) has become the backbone of the company.
has become such an integral part of travel business worldwide, that it holds enough sway to single-handedly make or break a hotel depending on how that hotel is portrayed on the Trip Advisor website.
, offers a portfolio of travel sites
that can be searched simultaneously to explore prices. Jetsetter, founded in 2009 and acquired by
in 2013, acts as an online travel agency catering to customers searching for higher quality (higher price) accommodations.

The massive amount of user-generated content posted on Trip Advisor is an invaluable resource of feedback for hotels and Trip Advisor itself. With this feedback, Trip Advisor can conduct internal improvement efforts, in addition to working with hotels to improve the customer experience. To date, Trip Advisor has used the labor intensive and potentially biased method of manually analyzing a small subset of the reviews. The goal of this project, therefore, is to construct an automated system (software) for analyzing free-form text responses. The output of this analysis will include extraction of informative word pairs (e.g. “great location”) in addition to calculation of a sentiment score. Further details are given below.

proposed steps for constructing this system are as follows

This process includes grammar and spell checking, in addition to the removal of unrecognizable characters. Then each review is split into individual sentences and tokenized using built-in functions, such as those available through NLTK.
In order to do classification from sentence to topics, we firstly have to transfer each sentence into a binary vector. To achieve this, we
that contains all unique words. T
construct a matrix1 that has the number of rows as number of sentences and number of columns as number of all unique words.
is associated with one row in the matrix1. If a word appears, we denoted the corresponding place 1, otherwise 0. Hence we can construct all sentences into the binary matrix1.
On the other hand, we also construct a matrix2 that has the number of rows as number of sentences and number of columns as number of categories.
And if a sentence belongs to a certain category, we denoted that place ‘1’, other wise 0.
this way, each column of matrix2 represents a category of all sentences.
Each row of matrix2 represents the

We train all sentences in matrix1 with every column of matrix2. In this way, this forms a number of categories classifiers. Then we pass in a new sentence or adjective/ noun pair into each of the classifier to do prediction.

Random forests are an ensemble learning method for classification, regression and other tasks, that operate by constructing a multitude of decision trees at training time and outputting the class that is the mode of the classes (classification) or mean prediction (regression) of the individual trees.
In our cases, we pass in many rows in matrix1 with their corresponding topics in matrix2 as training set, and then use random forest to in python library

Perform sentiment analysis to provide sentiment scores from 0 (negative) to 1 (positive)

A key advantage of the organization of the reviews in this dataset is that each review is known to be a response to either the “what I loved” or “what to know” sections of the questionnaire. This information can be used to help infer the type of sentiment expressed in the review. We propose a Bayesian approach for combining this prior information with the proposed adjective sentiment score that is calculated using NLTK. A potential model is to assume a normally distributed prior with a mean of 0.3 for the sentiment of reviews from “what to know” and 0.8 for the sentiment of reviews from “what I loved,” in combination with a normal likelihood based on the text analysis.
Enhance user experience by displaying straightforward and informative overview of the key aspects of each hotel

A fully optimized data structure is created that provides the capability and functionality to store all of the extracted keywords, adjectives, and sentiment scores into corresponding classified categories for each hotel. This information will be presented in summary, with the option of full output, for ease of use by Trip Advisor. Visualizations will be presented with the text output for further insight (e.g. identifying trends).
